docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that taking an invigorating walk gives the brains of people 60 to 75 years old a good workout, sharpening both memory and judgment. Anaerobic exercise -- stretching and weight lifting -- did not produce similar cognitive improvements. The experiment was conducted at the University of Illinois and reported in the current issue of the journal Nature.

headline.main: Walking: a Good Workout for Older Minds

docs.abstract: New study suggests that taking invigorating walk gives brains of people 60 to 75 years old a good workout, sharpening both memory and judgment (M)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that taking an invigorating walk gives the brains of people 60 to 75 years old a good workout, sharpening both memory and judgment.    Anaerobic exercise -- stretching and weight lifting -- did not produce similar cognitive...

docs.lead_paragraph: One way or another, we all learn how to use the toilet when nature calls. But the routes taken to achieve that critical milestone have varied greatly through the years. The passive, let-the-child-tell-you-when-it's-time approach that prevailed at the turn of the century was discarded in the 1920's and 1930's in favor of a rigid method dictated by parents. Then came Dr. Benjamin Spock, who rejected absolute rules for toilet training with a warning that rushed, rigid training could fail and lead to behavioral problems. Parents were instead advised to observe their toddlers for signs of toilet readiness. In 1962, Dr. T. Berry Brazelton formalized this child-oriented approach, which has prevailed since.

headline.main: How to Keep Toilet Training From Being a Power Struggle

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reviews various approaches to toilet training over the years; notes that American Academy of Pediatrics stands behind child-oriented approach, warning parents not to push children into toilet training (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An unusual letter appears in the Correspondence column of this week's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine: two doctors from Children's Hospital in Worms, Germany, wrote about a 10-year-old patient who was admitted to the hospital after complaining of stomach pains. The boy explained that the pains began after he ate a meal, but he admitted an hour later that he had swallowed a small object.

headline.main: Unusual Case of Swallowed Toy Flashlight

docs.abstract: Letter in Correspondence column of The New England Journal of Medicine written by two doctors from Children's Hospital in Worms, Germany, describes case of 10-year-old patient who swallowed a small flashlight; it still worked after its removal from the boy's intestines; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The playful little boy scrambled all over his father's body-building equipment and mats -- normal behavior for an active 2-year-old exploring his world. But his parents soon discovered something that was not normal: their son had developed pubic hair, facial acne and an enlarged penis.

headline.main: Body Cream Linked to Premature Puberty

docs.abstract: Article in current issue of of Pediatrics describes 2-year-old boy's precocious development of pubic hair, facial acne and enlarged penis, and ascribes it to child's accidental exposure to testosterone cream his father uses in body-building regimen (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Antibiotic resistance is a growing problem in the United States as overuse and incorrect use of antibiotics causes bacteria to become resistant to the medicines that are supposed to destroy them. Most of the antibiotic prescriptions that are issued each year are used by children under 6, and this age group is more likely to be infected by highly resistant bacteria than any other segment of the population.

headline.main: When Antibiotics Are Used Too Often

docs.abstract: Antibiotic resistance is growing problem in United States as overuse and incorrect use causes bacteria to become resistant to medicines that are supposed to destroy them; questions about antibiotic dependency in children and how to avoid it are addressed in new book Breaking the Antibiotic Habit: A Parent's Guide to Coughs, Colds, Ear Infections and Sore Throats, by Dr Paul A Offitt, Dr Bonnie Fass-Offit and Dr Louis M Bell (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A walk down the aisle of any decent-size drugstore offers the best evidence of the changes taking place in the children's drug market, estimated at $450 million a year. Many over-the-counter medications are now available for infants and young children, in many more varieties than in the past, and their numbers seem to be growing.

headline.main: Line Is Blurring for Medicine and Candy

docs.abstract: Children's drug market is estimated at $450 million a year; many over-the-counter medications are now available for infants and young children, and in more varieties; some health experts question health benefits of some of those in growing cold-and-flu and pain relief categories; say plethora of products increases chance parent could give child wrong thing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration last week approved marketing of an adult epilepsy drug for the treatment of children with partial onset seizures. The drug, topiramate, was approved for children ages 2 to 12 who suffer from petit mal epilepsy, one of 20 types of seizure disorders. Petit mal occurs in only one part of the brain, in contrast with grand mal, which affects both sides of the brain.

headline.main: Epilepsy Drug Is Approved for Children

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves marketing of adult epilepsy drug, topiramate, for treatment of children with partial onset, or petit mal, seizures; topiramate is marketed under brand name Topamax by Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceuticals; 2.3 million Americans have epilepsy, about one-third of them children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With September on the horizon, families are making plans for the new school year as well as for the new after-school year. My family included. My 5-year-old daughter will play soccer and wants to take an art class, ballet and possibly gymnastics. My 9-year-old son will be in the school chorus and may add tennis lessons, but he has vetoed my suggestion to start piano.

headline.main: For Some Children, It's an After-School Pressure Cooker

docs.abstract: Essay by Susan Gilbert on danger of overprogramming children with after-school activities; one child psychologist calls it significant problem in upper-middle-class families intent on having their children involved with many activities and doing them well; some therapists contend that stress of being overbooked can push children who are susceptible to depression and anxiety over the edge; therapists try to help parents find right balance between enriching activity and downtime; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: With September on the horizon, families are making plans for the new school year as well as for the new after-school year. My family included.    My 5-year-old daughter will play soccer and wants to take an art class, ballet and possibly gymnastics....

docs.lead_paragraph: Before she arrived at Empresa Elementary School in Oceanside, Calif., Callie Tuck thought physical education classes were a bore. ''At my old school we didn't really do anything for gym,'' she said. ''We just went out in the playground and stood around.'' But now Callie, who is 9 years old, loves P.E., thanks to a new program called Sports, Play and Active Recreation for Kids (Spark), a comprehensive curriculum that promotes physical activity, inside the classroom and out.

headline.main: Program Aims to Counter Lack of Physical Fitness

docs.abstract: New program called Spark (Sports, Play and Active Recreation for Kids) is intended to increase children's level of physical activity; program is conducted in 600 schools in 15 states; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that fewer than one-quarter of children engage in daily vigorous activity; one obstacle is fact that some parents and educators view physical education classes as expendable in shuffle of academic priorities and fiscal constraints; Dr James Sallis, creator of Spark, argues that daily PE helps students learn; photo (M)
